is that it doesn't have a deep water port, so it's not accessible by big cruise ships, but some smaller ships stop there. The

There is a local taxi and some local shuttle services. The local roads are also nice for bicycling, although the size of the island limits the overall distance one can travel.  Rental cars are available from both the hotels in town. Boats can even be rented from the Scandia House.

value: content=the southernmost tidewater glacier in the northern hemisphere. The glacier moves extremely quickly, offering almost continual calving, including underwater calving leading to "shooters" as icebergs rise rapidly to the surface from the hundreds of feet of submerged ice. Hundreds of harbor seals also inhabit the fjord created by the glacier; closer to the face you're likely to see them lolling about on icebergs.

- as Petersburg is located on the south end of Frederick Sound, where many humpback whales summer, it is an ideal starting point for whale watching. Although it's less comfortable to be out on the sound during rougher weather, days with lots of waves are better for seeing aerial displays.
content=Mile 14.2 on Mitkof Highway A boardwalk through the muskeg to Blind Slough, where the salmon are numerous and other wildlife is often visible.

Wilderness kayak camping tours to Frederick Sound to view humpback whales and other marine wildlife. Also kayak tours to the LeConte Glacier to paddle among the icebergs. Tour lengths of one week, three days, and one day available. 360-378-5767 or 888-589-4253, whales@sea-quest-kayak.com
http://www.sea-quest-kayak.com/sea-kayaking-trips-kayak-tours-alaska.htm/ Sea Kayaking Tours from Petersburg, Alaska
Behind the school there's a boardwalk through the muskeg (extremely soft nutrient poor meadow) that's worth walking.

Because Petersburg doesn't have a deep water port, it doesn't get the large cruise ships; thus, it isn't overrun with the large cruise line operated tourist shops that plague many such coastal towns. There are a few little locally owned galleries with local artists, and a bookstore with some nice coffee table books, but most of the town actually exists for the local population.

value: Assorted fried seafood and daily specials in a take-out ambiance, but the real treats are the vacuum packed smoked fish in the cooler.  Great breakfast sandwiches too.

Genuine Mexican food served in Kito's Kave on Sing Lee Alley.
Pizza, wings, burgers and other American fare.  Ice cream is available.
A sandwich shop with healthier choices.
Located at about 4 mile of Mitkof Highway this summertime restaurant and bar primarily serve local seafood from a limited but tasty menu.

There are two bars open to the public.  Harbor Bar is located on main street and Kito's Kave is a short distance away on Sing Lee Alley.  There are Moose and Elk's lodges for members as well.  All establishments are smoke-free as of 2010.

value: The newer hotel.  Has a jacuzzi suite available.  Located in the center of downtown.  Has a coffee shop on the first floor.
